title: Is the information in the book The Secret still properly called a secret? - Quora

response.answer_text: In my view “a secret” can be blantantly overt and still be more or less ignored, undetected because it is mostly over and under eyes, noses and heads, eluding thresholds of conscious awareness. In other words a “secret” can be revealed, including “indirectly” so that, for example a particular political ideology that will have adherents that formulate validations with an “implied obedience.” Thus, a “secret” does not have to be spelt out and the “reader(s)” can fill in their own subjective justifications to keep the secret or to spill the beans. But “spilling the beans” does not require that anyone should understand the secret, nor that it would make any difference. The secret can also act like a “seed” where the implantation of information can skid in patterns across time. That is, one book does not have to reveal the entire secret, and even if it does, it would be up to the writer to position the nodes of association that provide the image of the secret so that only some “get it.” I would suggest that most of us don’t have a clue what the secret is in “THE SECRET.” Given that it would be both a secret/non secret because some know the secret.

se·cret /ˈsēkrit/ adjective not known or seen or not meant to be known or seen by others.noun something that is kept or meant to be kept unknown or unseen by others. Maybe it’s just me, but it would seem that the act of researching, writing, publishing, and selling books about something sort of makes it no longer a “secret.”
